把下面这部分删除了:
2.3 AI-Oriented Discussion
Foundation-model significance. The paired heatmaps and ROC curves show that a TabPFN-
style encoder augmented with TCA delivers consistent gains over strong baselines in both intra- and
cross-hospital evaluations (AUC 0.829 → 0.705). This empirically validates the feasibility of com-
bining tabular foundation models with unsupervised domain alignment, extending recent small-data
evidence [5] and reinforcing the foundation-model view that large-scale priors can be transferred to
constrained clinical cohorts [4].
Generalization beyond pulmonary nodules. Because the architecture operates on generic clin-
ical tokens and the adaptation layer only requires unlabeled target data, PANDA’s formulation is
not tied to lung cancer. The demonstrated robustness under severe class imbalance suggests similar
benefits for other rare-disease registries or even non-medical small-sample problems where annotated
data are scarce, highlighting wider AI relevance.
Efficiency and scalability. Feature-selection curves (Figure 3c) indicate that, once distilled to
eight variables, training a fold completes within seconds. This mirrors TabPFN’s hallmark ability
to replace hours of hyper-parameter search with a single forward pass [5]. Pre-training therefore
amortizes optimization cost, while the fixed encoder + TCA workflow scales to additional hospitals
without end-to-end retraining, offering a pragmatic blueprint for multi-site deployments.
Interpretability and transparency. The final model exposes attention maps and permutation
importances for the retained features, aligning with explainable feature-selection principles [12] and
attention-based tabular models such as TabNet [1]. Clinicians can inspect why upper-lobe location,
NSE, and ventilatory metrics drive predictions, meeting the AI community’s push for transparent yet
accurate models.
Taken together, the TCA-enhanced tabular foundation model demonstrated robust external per-
formance and outperformed both machine learning and clinical baselines, validating its potential for
reliable deployment in real-world multi-center settings.

4. Comprehensive Clinical Validation Framework: We establish a rigorous multi-institutional
evaluation protocol using real-world data from two major cancer centers, demonstrating not only
superior predictive performance (AUC 0.709, sensitivity 94.4%) but also clinical utility through
calibration analysis and decision curve evaluation. Our validation approach sets new standards
for evaluating cross-institutional medical AI systems.
